conclusion: To solve the problem, we need to determine the magnitude of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in the coil.
The EMF induced in a rotating coil in a magnetic field is given by the formula: \( \mathcal{E} = n B A \omega \sin(\omega t) \)
\( n \) is the number of turns in the coil, \( B \) is the magnetic induction intensity, \( A \) is the area of the coil, \( \omega \) is the angular velocity, \( t \) is the time.

premise: The area \( A \) of the rectangular coil is given by: \( A = l_{AB} \cdot l_{BC} = 0.2 \mathrm{m} \cdot 0.5 \mathrm{m} \)
conclusion: The area \( A \) of the rectangular coil is \( 0.1 \mathrm{m}^2 \)
The magnetic induction intensity \( B \) is given as \( 0.1 \mathrm{T} \), the number of turns \( n \) is 100, and the angular velocity \( \omega \) is \( 100\pi \mathrm{rad/s} \).

premise: Substituting these values into the EMF formula, \( \mathcal{E} = n B A \omega \sin(\omega t) \)

conclusion: Since the timing starts when the coil plane passes through the neutral plane, the initial angle is \( \theta = 0 \), and the sine function will start at 0.
However, the maximum value of the sine function is 1, so the maximum EMF is: \( \mathcal{E}_{\text{max}} = 100\pi \cdot 1 = 100\pi \mathrm{V} \)
